intro: Fraxinus dubia, commonly known as the Mexican ash, is a deciduous tree native to Mexico and parts of Central America. It typically grows to a height of 10–15 meters and has smooth, gray bark that becomes fissured with age. The tree produces small, greenish-yellow flowers in pendulous clusters, followed by samaroid fruits that are dispersed by wind. Its leaves are alternate, simple, and ovate with a serrated margin. The plant is often found in moist, well-drained soils in tropical and subtropical regions.
